resources.string: What stance is the trick approached on?
How many degrees of rotation are performed in the air before landing?
Was a grab performed in the air?
Was a shifty performed while in the air?
What pop is used to get off the ground?
What type of feature is the trick done on?
What direction is the feature approached on?
Is the rotation getting onto the feature less than a full 180 degree turn?
What way is the board initially on the feature?
Is a press performed while on the feature?
Is an about 180 degree rotation or more performed while coming off of the feature?
Is a tail or nose tap performed while coming off of the feature?
Is the feature tapped with the nose or the tail?
What part of the board is on top of the feature?
Is the rotation after coming off of the feature about 90 degrees or less?
What way is the trick landed after coming off the feature?
Is the rotation after coming off of the feature about 270 degrees?
Is the direction of rotation the same or opposite direction of rotation of the previous move?
Which amount of rotation is about what is performed coming off of the feature?
Which amount of rotation is about what is performed getting onto the feature?
Does the front or the back of the board pass over the feature first?
Is more than a 180 degree spin continued while on the feature?
How many spins in total were performed from start to beginning of the trick?
How many spins are performed in the air before landing on the feature?
How many spins are performed in the air after getting off the feature?
Is a 180 degree rotation done in the air before hitting the stall on the feature?
Is a 180 degree rotation done just after stalling on the feature?
What part of the board is in contact to the feature when fully stalled on the feature?
Is a press over the trailing foot performed while stalled?
What type of feature is being tapped?
Does the board stay on the ground through during the trick or gets off the ground?
Which side of the board is being pressed at the beginning of the trick?
Is any rotation performed during this trick?
Is there a pause in the rotation at about 90 degrees of rotation?
Is the rotation after the pause: 90 degrees in either direction or 270 degrees in the opposite direction?
Is the last 90 degree rotation the same or opposite direction of the last rotation?
How many degrees of rotation are preformed while pressed?
Is the rotation after the pause: 90 degrees in either direction or 270 degrees in the same direction?
Are one or both hands being put on the ground behind the board?
Does the back leg stay extended when the hands are on the ground or bent?
Are one or both hands on the ground at some point in this trick?
Is a 180 degree or 360 degree rotation made during this trick?
Is the rotation done about 90 degrees or less, including no rotation?
Is the trick approached going up an incline and performed at the top of transitioning back down it?
Is the nose of the board pressed hard into the ground and the back hand grabbing anywhere around the tail?
Is the tail of the board pressed hard into the ground and the front hand grabbing anywhere around the nose?
Select number in increments of 180 degree rotations.
Select an available grab using the image below or type it in if you cannot find it.
Select an available feature or type it in if not found.
Choose the category of trick that the trick you are looking for falls under.

Choose a feature that describes what the trick was performed on. The 3 most common features are boxes, rails, and pipes. Boxes will have a flat, white-ish top. Rails are most always metal and thin, similar to the handrails of a staircase. Pipes (or tubes) have a hollow middle. Features come in a practically endless variety of shapes and positions so if you have a more specific name for the feature, select Other and type in it.
A trick performed where the snowboard lifts off the ground off of an allocated jump with a ramp.
A trick that can be performed on flat ground or off mellow hills, often starting with the snowboarders weight over the nose or tail of the snowboard.
A trick that is performed across a surface that is not snow, such as rails, boxes, trees, etc.

The great thing about butter tricks is that you can almost always connect multiple butter tricks together as long as they are all performed in one fluid motion. Endless possibilities! If this trick is not the last one performed of a combination butter trick, click CONTINUE to chain on another trick. Press Try again to restart this search. Press Complete if this is the full trick.

Press the SAVE button to save this trick as shown above to the My Trick List or to the Tricks To Do List. You can get the shorter and more slangy name of the trick by pressing Shorten. If this was not the trick you were looking for, you can press Try again or exit.

This question refers whether the rider is starting the trick in their dominant and most comfortable stance (Natural) or their non-dominant (Switch). A stance can have either foot leading down the slope: the left foot called Regular or the right foot called Goofy. If you are not sure if the trick starts Natural or Switch, or it is irrelevant, click Skip.

Select Yes if there is at least a full 180 degrees of rotation (half a full rotation) done from the moment right before going airborne to when the trick is landed. This is the amount of rotation of the board.

Direction of rotation is one of two ways, defined by what side of the body of the rider is facing down the hill in the first 90 degrees of rotation: the front of the body (Frontside) or the back of the body (Backside).
An inversion is defined as the head being below the head of the rider. If at any point while in the air this is true, select Yes.
The inversion direction can have either the head going back behind the body (Back) or the head going in front of the body (Front).

Pop is describing the way the rider uses the board to jump off the ground. They can transfer their weight over their back foot, springing off the tail of the board (Ollie). They can transfer their weight over their front foot, springing off the nose of the board (Nollie). They can have their weight centered over the board, jumping with the board flat on the ground (Straight). If you are not sure or it is irrelevant to this trick, select Straight.
A grab is the act of grabbing the board with one of either hands or both at the same time while airborne.
Use the image to select the an available grab or if it is not an option select Other to type one in.
A shifty is the act of counter rotating the board separate of the riders body while in the air and bringing the counter rotation back to the proper position being landing.

A Slide is literally sliding across a feature from one end to the other. A Stall is approaching a feature on a slight incline and stopping on that feature and coming off the feature back down the side it was approached on, similar to the act of going up and down the side of a halfpipe. A Tap is jumping over a feature and quickly hitting the feature with the board while passing it.
The Nose is the leading end of the board. The Tail is the trailing end of the board. If you are not sure what it is or it is irrelevant, select Skip.

The way a feature is approached is defined by what way the feature is facing the rider. The feature in front of the rider (Frontside) or the feature to the back of the rider (Backside) or going straight at the feature (Straight On).

When fully stopped on the feature, is the board in contact to the feature in between the rider feet/bindings (In between Feet), or on or past the riders back foot (Trailing Foot). The back foot being the foot going uphill.

This is asking about the rotation done in between the moment the board leaves the snow to the moment the rider lands on the feature. Also the rotation is about the boards movement, the rotation or lack rotation of the rider themselves is irrelevant.

This is asking about the rotation done in between the moment the board leaves the feature to the moment the rider lands back on the snow. Also the rotation is about the boards movement, the rotation or lack rotation of the rider themselves is irrelevant.

This question is asking about the rotation of the board itself from the moment the board gets off of the feature to when the board lands back on the snow. It does not count as a 180 rotation unless the board is riding away straight and not on an edge.
Answer Yes if the rider transfers their weight over their foot on the uphill side while on the feature. It will also look like the rider is poking the nose of their board over the feature.

The rider can get on a feature 3 different ways: on the feature without any rotation and riding on it straight with the board in contact with the feature along the entire length of itself (50-50), a slight rotation about 90 degrees where the front/leading end of the board goes over the feature and the board is sliding perpendicular on the feature (Boardslide), or a slight rotation about 90 degrees where the back/trailing end of the board goes over the feature and the board is sliding perpendicular on the feature (Lipslide).

Answers in degrees of rotation and it about the amount of rotation of the riders board, regardless of the riders body. 180 being a half a full rotation and 270 three quarters of one. If it is clearly not a 180 degree rotation but not exactly a 270, select 270 as it can be not exactly 270 degrees.

A press can be on the nose, the leading end of the board (Front), or the tail, the trailing end of the board(Back). It is performed when the riders weight is transferred over the nose (Nose Press) or the tail (Tail Press). The opposite end of the board should be off the ground if properly pressed.

According to the foot positioning of the rider at the start of the trick before jumping off the snow to get on the feature, the board could have the feature under the leading foot, over the trailing foot, or in between the feet/bindings. Note if it is over the leading foot or the trailing foot, the rider weight should be transferred over said foot.
According to the foot positioning of the rider at the start of the trick before jumping off the snow to get on the feature, it can be the front/leading foot (Front) or the back/trailing foot (Back).

This spin must have the rotation done while on the feature and be at least half a full rotation. The board will stay in contact with the feature through the spins. This continual spinning while on the feature is most commonly and easily done on a box feature, but it is possible on other features.

This question refers whether the rider ends the trick in their dominant and most comfortable stance (Natural) or their non-dominant (Switch). A stance have either foot leading down the slope: the left foot called Regular or the right foot called Goofy. If you are not sure if the trick ends Natural or Switch, or it is irrelevant, click Skip.

This would involve jumping off the feature just before reaching the end and while in the air using one end of the board to literally hit the feature. The can be done with the front/leading end of the board (Nose) or the back/trailing end of the board (Tail).

This only has to do with the boards rotation, the riders body is irrelevant. You will have the board make a rotation getting onto the feature. Is the next act of rotation the same or the opposite direction of that first act of rotation.

Remember if you are finding a trick that has more than one butter trick done in the full motion, you are only answering this question according to the single part of the full trick you are describing. This is important because the trick can involve one of the trick done while with the board in contact with the ground and the another with the board coming off the ground.

Remember if you are finding a trick that has more than one butter trick done in the full motion, you are only answering this question according to the single part of the full trick you are describing. This is important because the trick can involve one of the trick done without any rotation and the another with rotation. Also rotation refers only to the boards rotation, the riders body is irrelevant.

If Yes, the first move of this specific butter will be 90 degrees of rotation followed by a clear period of time with no rotation after the initial 90 degrees. Remember the rotation refers only to the boards rotation, the riders body is irrelevant.
The back leg is the trailing leg or the leg on the uphill side of the slope at the time of preforming this trick.
Similar to the way a trick is performed at the top of a halfpipe, this will be performed in the process of transitioning back down the incline.
This will involve the length of the board being close to vertical when these actions are performed and the rider riding away after this back the way the trick was approached.
The last rotation refers to the rotation of the initial rotation that stops at 90 degrees for a period of time. Answer if the following rotation is in the same or opposite direction of rotation.

An Aerial for this apps purposes is defined as a trick where the rider is airborne and the trick is done off a purposefully allocated jump, so generally an artificial jump. This can include drop offs and side hits to your own discretion but should not include mellow hills or bumps as those are reserved for Butters. The start of an Aerial trick is marked by the moment just before going airborne and ends when the board lands back on the ground. Anything done before or after these two points are not a part of the trick. The start and end of the trick is important to note when answering future questions. Can define flatspins and inversion but not tricks that involve both at the same time like corks or rodeos.

A Butter for this apps purposes is defined as a trick done on flat ground or mellow hills. Any butter that you find in this tree is "relatively" simple and describes a single move. Many butter tricks are a combination of these simple tricks put back-to-back in one fluid motion and you will be able to chain together a combination butter in this search by defining each part separately. Because the trick can have multiple parts, the trick must be looked at closely to divide it into each move, which can be defined by a change of press, rotation, etc. If the board goes airborne, everything done in the air until the board is back on the ground defines a single move. If the riders weight is centered over the board with it flat on the ground for anything more than a slight moment, that marks the end of the butter trick. The trick starts when a press is performed or the board goes airborne.

A Jib is a trick done riding the board across a non-pisted surface AKA anything that is not snow. Boxes, rails, trees, houses, balls, anything. The variety of features to jib on are practically endless so you are given the ability to name the feature your self, but the most common features to find in a park are boxes and rails. Note that because the variety is endless, this search cannot cover everything. It covers practically any trick on standard park features, NOT including change-ups/switch-ups done while on the feature or any butters done on the feature other than a nose and tail press. The start of the trick is marked by the moment the board leaves the snow to get on the feature and ends when the snowboard lands back on the snow.
Try holding down on the answers to see a more detailed description of what it is
This butter in full is called:
Are you sure you want to discard this search and start another one?
Are you sure you want to exit \"ADDING A TRICK\"? Any current progress will be lost.
No tricks completed yet. Add a trick by pressing the button below to find a trick by answering a series of questions or press the top right button to add a trick manually.
No tricks on the To Do list. Add a trick by pressing the button below to find a trick by answering a series of questions or press the top right button to add a trick manually.
Do you want to save this trick to your Tricks Completed List or to your Tricks To Do List?
This trick is already saved in your Tricks Completed List. Do you want to replace it with this trick?
This trick is already saved in your Tricks To Do List. Do you want to replace it with this trick?
Press one more time to exit app
Is this trick completed or something to do?
Find any problems, bugs, typos, things that should be added, false information, etc.? Email me notes, suggestions, and feedback. Please be specific about the where, when, and how?
Are you a jibber or something?
Icon for the title of the trick that will be displayed in the list
Icon for the alternate name of the trick that will not be displayed
Icon for the category of this trick
Icon for the date of the trick
Icon for what list the trick should be in
Icon for the extra notes on this trick
Go to search to find a trick by answering a series of questions
Image to expand a trick to see all parts of it and possibly edit it
Image with examples of common features
Cycle through available image diagrams for identifying a grab
Image of grab diagram to identify a grab
Notes, descriptions, location, or information about this trick
